They have all their available apples ready for tasting.  I found I have a new favorite apple.... the Empire - you gotta taste one!  A slice of apple pie ale mode and hot cider is worth the wait in the long line.  On weekends you can listen to live music while you wait.  My daughter loved the pony rides and we enjoyed the horse drawn wagon tour of the orchard.
review.author: Amy E.

review.description: Went there this weekend was packed- way too many people- has lot of stuff for kids, it is fun but try and go on a weekday to avoid the crowds
review.author: Lola M.

review.description:
I apparently missed the sign explaining where to go to pick your own apples. Had I picked my own, I probably would have gone up a star or two. That said, it was an enjoyable way to spend a couple of hours as long as I was in the area.

As other Yelpers have recommended, the apple donuts are very good. I enjoyed sitting in the barn, eating a BBQ pork sandwich with hot apple cider while listening to a bluegrass band. 

I took a short horse-drawn ride around the orchard for $3. Any opportunity to be pulled around by Clydesdales is fun, and the staff were very friendly, but I had hoped they'd drop us off at a pick-your-own outpost of some sort -- they didn't.

One of the main attractions appears to be the store. It's disappointing to spend that much time looking at trinkets and jars of jam when I'd hoped to spend a beautiful autumn day outside. That said, I did end up buying a bottle of apple BBQ sauce, caramel corn puff things and a gallon of apple cider.

I had fun, but I'm not sure it'd be worth the drive if I lived in the city.
review.author: Amelia W.

review.description:
I just went to Edwards Apple Orchard this past weekend (Saturday)and here are the pros and cons:
PROS:
Beautiful landscaped grounds
Nice tractor ride to pick your own apples
Free kids playground and animals to look at
Horse drawn wagon ride (for a fee)
Old fashioned corn husking demonstration (free)
Barn has lots for sale
Great cider donuts, apple pie and cider for sale
Nice music band outside (free)
CONS:
Absolutely overrun with people
Hour long wait for a hot dog
20 min wait for donut or slice of apple pie
15+ minute wait for a ladies bathroom
Animals are for looking at through a fence (no petting or feeding)
No where to sit  to eat your food after waiting an hour
Wall to wall people in the barn with a waiting line just to go in and browse

I live in Chicago.  This is not worth the drive from there.
Too many great places closer and with more attractions.  It may be worth it for people who live near Poplar IL.
review.author: Pai R.

review.description:
Went here on the last weekend to grab some cider and some apple butter before the official closing for the season.  They have a great selection of decorations for the holidays along with different items for the kitchen like salsa, butters and such.  They also have a small cafe in the basement with hot apple cider, doughnuts, and other sandwiches to consume while there.

This has been a great place to go with the family for years and I cant wait to go next year.
review.author: Jvontai H.

review.description:
A group of girlfriends and I headed out of the city for a day to enjoy some good, old-fashioned apple orchard fun!

From my place in the Ukrainian Village, it was about an hour and a half drive.  Not bad!  

We arrived and were kinda stunned at how crazy it was.  The last time I was there (when I was a kid), it was a small operation.  They've clearly hit the big time since then.  It was packed!  

We got on the tractor and headed out to the pick your own.  A note for other pickers - if you can, bring your own baskets for picking, otherwise you'll pay $3 for one of theirs.  They were picking Jonathans and Empires on the particular day we went out there.  The Jonathans were great - the trees weren't at all picked over and we filled up a basket pretty quickly!  The Empires weren't as good - the trees were a lot more picked over and there wasn't much left.  But we did well enough with the Jonathans that we were happy.

They also have a pick your own raspberry patch (which we skipped as my friend is allergic) and a pumpkin patch (where we found lots of little pumpkins for my friend's niece).  I think they may also have strawberries when they are in season, but don't quote me on that.  

There was a bluegrass band, big barn with lots of lunch-y type foods, a smaller snack shop with apple pie and apple donuts, and a shack that sold cider by the glass and bottles of water.  There were pony rides, hay rides, and lots of playgrounds for the kids.  Their country shop was amazing - lots of apple-themed products and yummy local foods made by farmers.  I picked up homemade vidalia dressing, sweetcorn salsa, and real cheese curds.  Yum!  It also sells pre-picked apples, so I took home two big bags full of honeycrisps.  

All in all we had a lot of fun here.  Next time I'd probably try to find somewhere that's less crowded and has a better variety of apples for u-pick, but if someone suggested it, I'd happily come back here for more apple fun!
review.author: Kim J.

review.description:
What a great place!

Love coming on weekends in October, although crowded, it adds to my experience AND most importantly....baked potato tent!!! Love the apples, the fudge, the cheese, the apple pie, the baked potatoes, the jam, the apple cider, everything!
review.author: Cheryl R.

review.description:
On Sunday, we took a drive northward towards the Wisconsin border for a day of apple picking and general autumnal fun.  Our original destination was Royal Oak orchard in Harvard but since I couldn't be bothered to actually log onto their website, I didn't realize they don't open on Sundays.  I should've known because if you've ever been to Royal Oak, it's a beautiful place but they do kind-of hit you over the head with the bible the whole time you're there - my mother loves it.  So I tapped furiously on my Tom-Tom navigation device and found Edwards Apple Orchard.  The drive from Harvard, IL to Poplar Grove, IL is nice enough - we saw lots of farms and a handful of little villages; very Norman Rockwell.  Not knowing anything about Edwards and feeling slightly bummed that Royal Oak was closed, we crossed our fingers and hoped for a halfway decent afternoon.  Our expectations were met and exceeded by Edwards.

The place was hopping for a mid-September Sunday.  The parking situation wasn't too bad - they have parking on either side of Centerville Rd and they have cops there to make sure the whole operation moves efficiently and safely.  Once you get on the property, they have a lot of the same stuff they have at other farms - apple picking, pony rides, petting zoo, country store, tractor rides... you get the picture.  The one thing they don't do is take plastic.  We rarely have cash on us and use our debit card almost exclusively so this was a bit of an inconvenience.  They do have an ATM in the store which charges the very standard $1.50 per transaction.  I hated to do it but we had come so far and there probably wasn't a TCF bank anywhere in the vicinity, so I gritted my teeth and pulled out the cash.  The one thing Edwards does very well, compared with other orchards we have historically visited, is crowd control.  Does everyone go nuts for cider-donuts or is it just me?  Edwards makes you to stand in line and they have sacks of donuts ready to go.  At Royal Oak, Apple Holler, Didier Farms and almost everywhere else I can remember, it's a clusterf*** to get those donuts.  I don't know why we go so crazy for cider-donuts but it's one of those things I wait all year for and when a place like this makes it easy for me to get my fix, I appreciate it.  The rest of the store is like a giant Cracker Barrel which my wife loves - I had to hold my son so he wouldn't break anything.  A jar of honey, four taffy apples, two lollipops and a tub of caramel made our wallet $30 lighter but *DANG* those apples are so good.  So now you're armed with cash and can start 'having fun' - what else can you do?  They have a little area with farm animals - I called it a petting zoo but that's not accurate... you don't go in with the animals... they are in a barn and you can reach in and pet/feed them.  Don't bother buying any animal feed because these guys are so full that they usually sniff your hand and ignore the food.  That 'farm animal experience' doesn't cost anything - that's a freebie @ Edwards.  They have a playground with old tractors and slides for kids - also free.  There are lots of kids everywhere and their respective parents snapping pictures.  Next, we decided to take a Clydesdale drawn ride around the property and follow that up with a pony ride for the little ones - clearly the free fun ended here since both of those attractions run about $4 per person (expensive - no?).  Then we decided to do the actual apple picking.  They get you on a trailer (pulled by tractor) and explain that you must use one of their baskets (which you end up purchasing) and must fill it with at least $30 worth of apples - this is the minimum amount of apples you must purchase - if you take less than $30 worth of apples you still pay $30.  You won't know exactly how much your basket of apples will cost until it gets weighed later, but apparently you have to at least put $30 in there (or else).  I was slightly confused by the system, but it didn't really matter.  They drive you back to the orchard and tell you which apples you can pick - on this specific day, it was Jonathan and Jonagold apples.  Let me tell you these apples were absolutely magnificent.  You can fill a basket full of PERFECT apples in just a matter of minutes... I do like the apples here.  I don't have one of Royal Oak's apples to do a Pepsi challenge but I bet Edwards can hold their own.

So now we have a giant basket full of beautiful and delicious apples (of which we will sadly only eat maybe half).  I should be thankful that Royal Oak was closed on the day of our lord otherwise we may have never discovered Edwards orchard.
review.author: ALFREDO M.

review.description:
Edwards Orchard has a history that dates over fifty years, and I think it is because of this that my family and I have been going here for Apple-picking for over 10 years.  Because it is also family-owned, it's family  feel is what brings us back every year!

As you approach the orchard with the car windows down, you are hit with the smell of their apple donuts.  On weekends, you can find a band playing while you sit in their picnic area and enjoy their hot or cold cider, barbeque pork sandwiches, baked potatoes, etc.  from their restaurants.

You are brought to the apples by a "hay-less" ride, I know some orchards allow you to drive through their orchards, but not this one.  One thing, they do have a variety of different kinds of apples to pick, but you have to know exact dates when they're available to pick or you'll just have to pick what they have on the day you go.  For example, I went yesterday, and we were hoping to pick some Gala Apples, but apparently they were harvested earlier in the month.  Therefore, we had to pick Golden and Red Delicious apples.  I also wish they had a petting zoo, and a corn maze, I know some others do.  

Last but not least, it's not too far from the city, about an hour to an hour and a half.  Also, this place is VERY clean!!!  And make sure to bring cash or your checkbook, they do NOT take credit.

Overall-
Cleanliness:  A
Food:  A
Location:  A
Price:  B
Service:  A
---------------------
Grade:  A
review.author: Andie W.

review.description:
The barn was rebuilt due to the tornado in January 2007 I believe.

The new barn is all I have seen and it is sooo nice. The best are the donuts. Everyone here in this area are addicted to them. The pumpkin or carrot roll is very good too. So many things to buy in the barn. It is warm and welcoming. Cute trinkets, Christmas stuff. Oh, and I love those caramel puffs.

Crowds can be big. Maybe better to go later in the season. Closes in November. My family had a tradition of coming out here even before I moved here. My stepmom buys bags of stuff (maybe too much)!

Awesome place!
review.author: Therese F.

review.description: Read the rave reviews, and I'm not feeling it.  This is literally the busiest apple orchard I have ever visited.  They do not accept credit or debit cards...  but do have ATM's on property if you don't mind paying the service charge for getting cash there.  It's big and has a few novelty attractions, but I didn't see much of a difference between this place and some of the smaller orchards in the area.  They all tend to have the same basics (play area, shop with items, fudge, cider, donuts, hay ride, etc.), which are really what most of us go to an orchard for.  I will say though, I didn't see a corn maze anywhere at this orchard.  People often say the donuts or cider tastes better from one orchard or another, but honestly, I'm not seeing it after visiting several orchards.  If we did a blind taste-test, I'm betting no one could tell the difference between any of them.  $30 - $35 to pick your own apples is way overpriced, even if it is "just for the experience."  The place is OK, but if you have a local orchard, you're probably just as well off going there (especially if you are driving any distance to get to this one).
review.author: J M.

review.description:
A trip to Edward's is one of my most favorite fall activities!!! Spent the day there and I have to say going during 80 degree weather in October seemed rather strange. I'm used to going while its chilly and enjoy a hot apple cider, but I still enjoyed my apple cider just chilled! There is a barn with lots of gourmet food goodies, halloween and fall craft/gift items, fresh fudge, apples galore and of course thier famous donuts which are to die for! I can't imagine leaving there without some honey crisps and a dozen donuts! Just know that they only accept cash and checks although I did see an atm machine nestled in a corner. Outside there is a pumpkin patch, farm animals and play area for the kids, tractors and even a horse drawn carriage trolley rides through the orchard. Check out the farm museaum in the eatery theres some cool things in there. Weekends are pretty busy but its really a great place to be enjoyed! There was also a band playing outdoors which helped add to the atmosphere. Can't wait to go back next fall!
I wish there were more signs on the road to direct you or show you where to turn because we nearly passed Centerville Rd.
review.author: Nicole S.

review.description: LOVELOVELOVELOVE this place. Nothing says fall than coming here during the week, getting 1/2 dozen donuts, gallon of cider, and some yummy Gala apples. Love their pumpkin butter, too. Can't believe they how quickly they build this place up from the tornado! I love both locations, both are beautiful country drives, but this location has them animals! Their donuts are the best. I wanna go now!
review.author: Mill V.

review.description: I never have been here and today was my first day visiting. Everything nearly was so over priced! Apples were $8-12 a small bag, apple cider donuts nearly $8 A dozen A $1.50 for a tiny glass of cider, $9.00 for A gallon of apple cider. I went to the basement to order some food it was $3 for a cup of mac n cheese $5 for a piece of pie with a scoop of icecream ontop. I bought food and cider for 2 people costed me over $20 HERE comes the fun part! When I went to the register the women told me CASH or CHECK ONLY! Nowhere in line did it say cash or check only I felt so stupid I left everything. She told me to go use the atm A warning about the atm it charges A huge service fee! I didnt buy anything! Whoever heard of A store not taking debit or credit these days? I came from Chicago and I dont carry more on me then A $10! I went outside and seen the goats and realized you could feed them only 1 problem you need A quarter I went inside to get some quarters the women wouldnt give me change she said she couldnt sorry.If you come here bring LOTS and LOTS of MONEY and dont forget the QUARTERS.
review.author: Mike A.

review.description: This place will always hold a special special place in my heart!  I absolutely love it there!! Wish I could give it 10 stars!  We've made it a tradtion to go every year.  My father lived in Candlewick & found this gem minutes away....We've been going a few times a year ever since.  Soo glad they rebuilt so fast! I think a lot of people would have been devastated if it did not reopen.  Their Cider doughnuts are AMAZING! so is their Cider, the BBQ sandwhich & their apple pie with melted cheddar over the top!...who would've known it would taste sooo good!  My family loves to pick apples- The Gala's are my favorite...the atmosphere is just great- we have soooo many people that tell us that they want to go with on our next visit...gotta reserve a charter bus I guess!
review.author: Charlene A.

review.description: A terrific way to spend a nice fall afternoon.  Come have a pulled pork sandwich, a piece of apple pie and some hot cider while you listen to the bluegrass band play.  There's a fairly large area for children to play and climb around, a fabulous gift shop in the barn and raspberries, pumpkins and apples you can pick yourself.  Hot, fresh cider donuts, popcorn balls, homemade fudge, hot and cold cider and of course apples are just some of the things you can pick up to take home with you.  Try it once and it's bound to become a family tradition for you too.  One thing to be aware of is it's cash or check only, no credit cards.  There is an ATM on site but come prepared.
review.author: amy j.

review.description: Oh, what to say...Tradition. Heritage.  Location, Location, Location.  A family-owned apple orchard in the middle of rural northern IL.  Just close enough to be a perfect fall day destination for the Chicago suburbs and just far enough from everything to be a local's favorite place for pie.  The cider is made right in the apple barn.  The donuts are made fresh all day long and the fudge is "just like grandma use to make".
review.author: Sarah I.

review.description: Terrific!  Easy parking and low lines; when the lines did get long, additional help seemed to be available.  Granted, we did go during a Bears game but I would definitely return.  Easy to get to via 90 (save the construction).  The apple donuts were indeed great!  The apples were a bit pricey at $37/buschel but for a family where you're not paying parking, I think it's well worth it.  Music, good food, apple pickin - cmon, what more do you want!
review.author: Keith E.

review.description: The apples are excellent and the fresh apple cinnamon donuts are addicting.  No matter how many donuts I purchase, they rarely survive the trip home.  Placing them in the trunk might be a suggestion for those who actually want to have some the next day. Having gone here for decades, it would seem their prices have increased far beyond the rising prices in today's economy. Perhaps it is supply and demand. I have often said about food 'if it is good, I don't care about the cost.'  Edwards has reached the point where I limit my visits to once a year versus several each year simply because the costs have really gone beyond an acceptable level. Another problem is they use cute baskets which do not hold more than two bags of apples, unless you want to bounce them on the floor several times.  If you are disabled or physically challenged, bring a helper, as you will not be able to manage carrying anything if you use a cane and the very few benches are usually occuppied by donut eaters and kids, so there is no place for the physically challenged.  They do have ample handicapped parking, but it would seem to be filled by those affluent people from the suburbs with handicapped parking permits who seem to be free of disabilities.
review.author: Elijah M.

review.description: We LOVE Edwards Apple Orchard and have been going every year for 7 years. It's a wonderful autumn experience. The apples and donuts are out of this world. It's just an overall, wonderful family experience!
